title: Teaching
text:
Below are the list of courses I have been a TA for at Texas A&M University. If you are seeking resources from POLS 209 or POLS 309, please click the link to the GitHub repository for it. If you are seeking resources from the other courses, please email me.

Current Courses
TA - Undergraduate Level
POLS 309: Polimetrics [Spring 2026, Prof. Crisman-Cox]
TA - Graduate Level
POLS 603: Quantitative Political Analysis II (MLE & GLMs) [Spring 2026, Prof. Crisman-Cox]


Past Courses
TA - Undergraduate Level
POLS 308: Game Theoretic Models in Political Science [Fall 2025, Prof. Matt Malis]
POLS 209: Introduction to Political Research Methods [Fall 2024, Fall 2025, Prof. Illayda Onder]
POLS 200: Foundations of Political Science [Fall 2023, Prof. Todd Kent]

title: Reshikesav (Reshi) Rajan
text:
Howdy! I am a PhD student in the Department of Political Science at Texas A&M University’s Bush School of Government in College Station, Texas.
My research interests are focused on both substantive and methodological interests. My substantive research interests are primarily in the intersection of comparative political behavior & political economy — specifically how economic institutions and features impact voting behavior. My methodological research interests are focused in quantitative methodology — particularly maximum likelihood estimation, generalized linear models, and time-series, spatial, and panel/TSCS data analysis.
I completed my B.A. in International Affairs with a minor in Mathematics from the University of Georgia in 2023 as well as my M.A. in Political Science.

title: CV
text: My CV can be found here.

title: Research
text:
My research currently focuses on both substantive and methodological interests. My substantive interests are in comparative political behavior and political economy, specifically looking at how electoral behavior is affected by economic institutions and features. I supplement this with methodological research questions focused on the ways we can improve our ability to estimate and interpret regression models with a particular emphasis on time-series, spatial, and time-series cross-sectional data.

Publications

Rajan, Reshikesav, and Shane P. Singh. 2025. “Toothless compulsory voting can increase turnout: Evidence from India.” Electoral Studies 96:102951. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.electstud.2025.102951.

Featured in UGA Today and ScienceBlog.




Software
tseffects: Software to estimate dynamic (causal) inferences and dynamic interaction effects with Soren Jordan and Garrett N. Vande Kamp.


Works in Progress

Causal Inference with Integrated Time Series using Differenced Variables with Soren Jordan and Garrett N. Vande Kamp. Under Review.
Ballot Box Blues: How Compulsory Voting Weakens the Impact of Economic Voting
Rage Against the Machine: What Australian Voters Can Tell Us About Rank-Choice Voting’s Implications
Visualizing the Dynamic Conditional Marginal Effects of Dynamic Regression Models with Multiplicative Interactions with Soren Jordan and Garrett N. Vande Kamp
